Comment: I’ll save you a click:  The results released Friday show Trump with an approval rating of 42 percent, while 54 percent said they disapprove of his job performance, putting him 12 points underwater in net approval.  Trump’s approval rating in the poll sits at just 29 percent with independents, who indicated they’re showing stiff resistance to many of his policies, siding more with Democrats in opposition than Republicans who still overwhelmingly back his administration.   Meanwhile, fewer than a third of independents said Trump understands the problems of people like them, and more than 60 percent said they view Trump as exceeding the powers granted to him.

Comment: You're presenting a caricature of how the body politic works. Information isn't this superfluid mental substance that penetrates every citizen's consciousness immediately and equally. Do you have conversations with random gas station attendants, people in waiting rooms or at dog parks or in the pickup queue of a school? You’ll find the most astonishingly partially informed or semi-misinformed attitudes. “I guess he got a few things wrong but he’s fixing it” or “I didn’t vote for him but I like how he’s standing up to China “ or the classic “maybe he’s a bit ruthless but at least he’s dealing with government waste / criminal gangs / those ‘woke’ people I’m not gonna admit I feel inferior to “.   Add in sexism, racism and antisemitism, which are a thing even among Democrats let alone potential Trump voters, and you see how he’s pushing the right buttons. The number of people who say crap like “feminism has gone too far” is after all similar.   If you want things to turn around, help out organizing. They won’t without.

Comment: It’s also worth a mention, before the apologists chime in saying: “you can’t gerrymander a state wide election” that yes, you can gerrymander a state wide election. Places like Ohio have been doing it for years. Ohio’s 68% unearned supermajority (for example) has been able to jerk around the electorate in ways that depresses turnout in more populated areas and makes it easier for GOP presidential candidates or senators to win in this state. Lines are routinely out the door for early voting in Franklin county. There was an hours long traffic jam the last weekend of early voting, and despite having almost a million people in the county Franklin only has one early voting location, like every county no matter the size. Now the supermajority wants to use their ill gotten power to do away with campaign finance oversight.
